p:
As in previous climate impact studies, a decrease in yield was simulated in rainfed fields between the baseline period and 2050 under the hypothesis of unchanged varieties and sowing dates (RCP4.5), with a negative effect in 70% of rainfed fields ( Fig. 3 D ). This negative effect was maximum at latitudes 43–47° N that represent the major growing area for maize. Conversely, simulated yields tended to increase in well-watered fields at latitudes higher than 47° N due to increased light intensity around flowering time (
SI Appendix, Fig. S10 F ). Overall, upscaling these results for Europe as a whole across latitudes resulted in a small effect on overall production in rainfed fields (−2% and +0.6% for RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, respectively) ( Fig. 4), with high negative effects in two GCMs out of six (
SI Appendix, Fig. S11 ). Irrigated fields had a yield slightly increased or decreased depending on GCMs (mean, +1.8% and +1.0% for RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, respectively). Yields, weighted for the proportion of irrigated/rainfed maize in the Eurostat 25 × 25 km grid cell (
SI Appendix, Table S1 ), were nearly unaffected in 2050 compared with baseline (mean, −0.8% and +0.8% for RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, respectively) if TE was considered as changing with CO 2 concentration. They were more affected if TE was considered constant in our simulations, due to more frequent water deficit, or if restrictions of water availability reduced the current portion of land area under irrigation ( 36).
